qas.question: How would the Empire style of France be characterized by comparison?
What was the origination of the Imperial Roman Style?
What was the corresponding style to Empire in Britain?
In the US, the style during this time of Neoclassical Empire was known as what?
What neoclassic style in France was less grandiose?
What took its name from the wall of Napoleon the second?
What did the colonial style in the United States correspond to?
What did Hugh Honour see as the culmination of the neoclassical movement?

context: At the same time the <b4_0><b5_0><b6_0>Empire style<b6_0/><b4_0/> in France<b5_0/> was a <a0_0>more grandiose<a0_0/> wave of neoclassicism in architecture and the decorative arts. Mainly based on Imperial Roman styles, it originated in, and took its name from, the rule of <a1_0>Napoleon I<a1_0/> in the First French Empire, where it was intended to idealize Napoleon's leadership and the French state. The style corresponds to the more bourgeois Biedermeier style in the German-speaking lands, <a3_0>Federal style<a3_0/> in the United States, the <a2_0>Regency<a2_0/> style in Britain, and the Napoleonstil in Sweden. According to the art historian Hugh Honour "so far from being, as is sometimes supposed, the culmination of the Neo-classical movement, the <b7_0>Empire<b7_0/> marks its rapid decline and transformation back once more into a mere antique revival, drained of all the high-minded ideas and force of conviction that had inspired its masterpieces".
